node.excerpt: As more people start tinkering with Om Next, similar questions keep popping up increasingly often. While this is a natural thing given any new learning efforts, there can never be too many resources when we start learning something new. This write-up is an attempt to get people up and running with Om Next's query syntax by providing comprehensive examples and a quick syntax reference for the future.

It has been a while since Martin Klepsch posted his Om Next reading list. If you're learning Om Next or planning to, there are a bunch more excellent resources that have recently appeared, and this post compiles a list of some of them.

frontmatter.title: clj-isitup - a simple isitup.org API client

fields.title: clj-isitup - a simple isitup.org API client

node.excerpt: For sometime around last year, I had been toying with a simple isitup.org API client and command line tool in Clojure. Just until a few days ago, it was just sitting in my GitHub page. Until I decided to put it out there.

frontmatter.title: Hosting files on the cloud via GitHub Issues

fields.title: Hosting files on the cloud via GitHub Issues

node.excerpt: Ever wanted to host pictures or other files on GitHub without storing them in a repository? Here's a simple hack which allows us to host our files directly on GitHub's cloud.

frontmatter.title: Solving Closure Library's Html5history double event dispatch

fields.title: Solving Closure Library's Html5history double event dispatch

node.excerpt: Most Clojurescript apps that rely on browser routing are wired in some manner to either the Google Closure Library's HTML5 History module or - in an increasingly lower number of cases - the History module. While both pushState- and fragment-based routing are supported, the module always dispatches two navigation events when opting for the latter, which can become a source of unexpected behavior. Here's how to fix it.
